issue.title: Current "main" branch: tests hang at 99%
issue.body:
MacOS Catalina 10.15.7, Xcode-12.2.

Config:
```
env RUN_TESTS_PARALLEL_UPPER=FALSE cmake -GNinja .. -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=ON -DOQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS=ON -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/opt/local -DOQS_KEM_DEFAULT="OQS_KEM_alg_ntru_hps4096821" -DOQS_SIG_DEFAULT="OQS_SIG_alg_falcon_1024" -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
```

comment.body:
> Could you change the name of the file `tests/helpers.py` to `tests/oqs_helpers.py` and also change the import statement in `tests/test_code_convention.py` .  .  .

Certainly. But since the code was written with the assumption that `helpers` was a safe term (like nobody else would ever name their stuff that, right?), it did not quite work (changing `import` in all those files did not help):
```
$ python3 -m pytest --verbose
```

issue.body:
MacOS Catalina 10.15.7, Xcode-12.2.

Config:
```
env RUN_TESTS_PARALLEL_UPPER=FALSE cmake -GNinja .. -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=ON -DOQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS=ON -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/opt/local -DOQS_KEM_DEFAULT="OQS_KEM_alg_ntru_hps4096821" -DOQS_SIG_DEFAULT="OQS_SIG_alg_falcon_1024" -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
```

Run tests:
```
$ ninja run_tests
```

comment.body:
Since making (reasonably) sure module `helpers` is not installed anywhere else, did **not** help:
```
.  .  .  .  .
tests/test_code_conventions.py::test_style PASSED                                                  [ 63%]
tests/test_code_conventions.py::test_spdx PASSED                                                   [ 64%]
tests/test_code_conventions.py::test_free ^C

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! KeyboardInterrupt !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.9/lib/python3.9/subprocess.py:1988: KeyboardInterrupt
(to show a full traceback on KeyboardInterrupt use --full-trace)
==================================== 244 passed in 204.46s (0:03:24) =====================================
```
and renaming `helpers.py` in the `tests/` directory to `oqs_helpers.py` did not help for other reasons (I didn't consider myself knowledgeable enough in Python to hack the resulting `oqs_helpers.py` to alleviate the newly-introduced problems), I have ot insist on my proposed solution. It may not be the most beautiful code, but it has one significant advantage over the current source - **it works**.

Again,
```diff
diff --git a/tests/test_code_conventions.py b/tests/test_code_conventions.py
index 39fce569..86fcf93b 100644
--- a/tests/test_code_conventions.py
+++ b/tests/test_code_conventions.py
@@ -3,6 +3,7 @@
 import helpers
 import pytest
 import sys
+import subprocess
 
 # Ensure every key-exchange algorithm in the code
 # is mentioned in the documentation.
@@ -50,10 +51,10 @@ def test_spdx():
 @helpers.filtered_test
 @pytest.mark.skipif(sys.platform.startswith("win"), reason="Not needed on Windows")
 def test_free():
-    files = helpers.run_subprocess(['find', 'src', '-name', '*.c'])
-    files = helpers.run_subprocess(['grep', '-v', 'picnic/external'], input=files.encode('utf8'))
-    lines = helpers.run_subprocess(['xargs', 'grep', '[^_]free('], input=files.encode('utf8'), ignore_returncode=True)
-    lines = lines.split("\n")
+    files  = subprocess.Popen(["find", "src", "-name", "*.c"], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
+    fliles = subprocess.Popen(["grep", "-v", "picnic/external"], stdin=files.stdout, stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
+    lines  = subprocess.Popen(["grep", "[^_]free("], stdin=fliles.stdout, stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
+    lines = lines.stdout.read()
     okay = True
     for line in lines:
         if line == "": continue
```

with the desired/expected result:
```
.  .  .  .  .
tests/test_kat.py::test_sig[SPHINCS+-SHAKE256-256s-robust] PASSED                                  [ 99%]
tests/test_kat.py::test_sig[SPHINCS+-SHAKE256-256s-simple] PASSED                                  [ 99%]
tests/test_namespace.py::test_namespace PASSED                                                     [100%]

=============================== 372 passed, 8 skipped in 67.55s (0:01:07) ================================
```

*My personal opinion/theory: the current `tests/helpers.py` overcomplicates what it's doing with `subprocess`. When there's **only one subprocess** active, like in all the other `tests/*.py`  files, it appears fine. In `test_free()` you're chaining together multiple subprocesses, and it blows. My fix avoids doing that, so it doesn't hit the "sour spot" that Python-3 might have, so it works.*

comment.body: Well, there's two more differences between your proposal and the current `helpers.py` code (that I'd also suggest renaming to something like `oqs_helpers.py`): STDERR is redirected to STDOUT. May that be the explanation? Could you retry without that line in `helpers.py`? The other difference is the missing `split("\n")`. Does your code also work with that added? Either way, wouldn't you want to submit a PR for these changes so we get this fixed for good?

comment.body:
> STDERR is redirected to STDOUT. May that be the explanation? 

I don't understand the consequences of that enough to comment.

> Could you retry without that line in `helpers.py`?

Why not... ;-)

> The other difference is the missing `split("\n")`. Does your code also work with that added?

Nope! Removing that line was necessary because my solution differs somewhat from yours. When I do `read()`, it automatically splits *and converts to `str`*. `split()` only works on `byte` (welcome to Python-3 ;) ).

> Either way, wouldn't you want to submit a PR for these changes so we get this fixed for good?

Well, I didn't plan to fork this repo (and the patch seemed small enough) - but if you insist...

comment.body:
> Well, I didn't plan to fork this repo (and the patch seemed small enough) - but if you insist...

Agree, it's probably quicker if I do it -- also to run CI on other platforms... Will surely credit you.

Did anything change when removing the STDERR redirect? Also, did you give a split() option a try to see whether that makes the difference on your platform? I'm still curious _what_ it really is....

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body: I personally never executed this under Win10. Do you encounter problems with it there? If unsurmountable ones, what about building in an Ubuntu VM (using e.g. VirtualBox)?

comment.body:
> Did anything change when removing the STDERR redirect?

Unfortunately, no.

Here's where the original code seems to get stuck:
```
.  .  .  .  .
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! KeyboardInterrupt !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.9/lib/python3.9/threading.py:316: KeyboardInterrupt
(to show a full traceback on KeyboardInterrupt use --full-trace)
======================= 370 passed, 8 skipped in 4091.42s (1:08:11) ====
```

As I said, something somehow gets screwed up with multi-threading/subprocesses.

> Also, did you give a split() option a try to see whether that makes the difference on your platform? 

`split()` fails with my code because it requires input of `byte` type, and what I'm doing produces `str`. 

Since the original code produces `byte`, it probably does need `split()`. Also, I inserted debugging prints in the `test_free()`, and they show that the execution never reaches past the 2nd `run_subprocess()`. 

> I'm still curious what it really is....

Aren't we all... ;-)

issue.title: disable pthreads testing for mem test
issue.body:
Implementation (preparation) for #439 (see discussion there) reusing existing test code.

@xvzcf , @dstebila : Please (re)confirm that `test_kem`/`test_sig` do not do more testing than desirable when setting the new `-mem` option.

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding or removing?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

comment.body:
>  I can imagine for evaluation purposes it would be desirable to see these reported separately.

Conceptually, I agree. Practically, this makes life a bit more difficult: How to run a decaps-only test without (the data from) a matching keygen and encaps before? Right now, as Valgrind/massif only reports results on a start-to-finish program execution and not only over certain functions, the only option I see is storing to file and reading back later for decap the (separate) keygen- and encap-run results (in separate(ly "valgrind"ed) program runs). Other ideas? Also, we'd need to refrain from using any serious "marshaling-to-file" concepts (XML, anyone? :-) as otherwise _those_ will be reported as the most heavyweight memory consumers. Let me do a quick implementation to see how such "shallow write/read" is visible to Valgrind...

That said, I just noticed another potential issue when creating a sample valgrind run for you to look at (see below): The "deepest" memory consumption is caused in this case by "OQS own" randombytes generation... What to do here? Fix randomness to say all-0 to just measure pure algorithm (memory consumption) performance? That approach however may not suit all algorithms requiring (T)RNG for proper operation... So I guess we've got to live with (measuring) that as all algorithms will be penalized in the same way.
Also on this, (other) thoughts welcome.

